pages.text: Thermal Cultivation adds a variety of crops, the seeds of which may be purchased from villagers. These crops can be harvested by right clicking with an empty hand. Mushroom crops may be planted on $(l:thermal:world/plants/phytogro)Phyto-Soil$(/l), Mycelium, or Podzol, but are unaffected by fertilizers such as Bone Meal. They are still affected by Phyto-Soil and $(l:thermal:equipment/tools/watering_can)Watering Can$(/l) growth bonuses.

pages.A.title: Amaranth
pages.A.text: A vibrant grain packed with nutrients and alchemical properties.
pages.B.title: Barley
pages.B.text: A cereal grain which can be ground into flour or malted to make beer or whiskey.

pages.A.title: Corn
pages.A.text: A staple grain prized for its versatility.
pages.B.title: Flax
pages.B.text: A fibrous plant that can easily be processed into string.

pages.A.title: Onion
pages.A.text: A bulbous vegetable that is often used to add flavor to a savory dish. Brings people to tears.
pages.B.title: Radish
pages.B.text: A root vegetable with a sharp flavor, typically eaten raw or steamed.

pages.A.title: Rice
pages.A.text: The most widely consumed staple grain in the world. Laborious to harvest.
pages.B.title: Sadiroot
pages.B.text: A medicinal spice known for its cleansing properties. Has a distinctive aroma.

pages.title: Spinach
pages.text: The leaves of a spinach plant. Grants sailors an increase in muscle mass.

pages.A.title: Bell Pepper
pages.A.text: A cultivar of peppers without the spice. Commonly chopped and used in dishes.
pages.B.title: Eggplant
pages.B.text: A purple, spongy $(l)fruit$() used in many dishes. Tends to absorb other flavors.

pages.A.title: Green Bean
pages.A.text: The immature seed pods of a bean plant. Can be consumed alone or cooked in various dishes.
pages.B.title: Peanut
pages.B.text: The seeds of a peanut plant. Often roasted, pressed into oil, or ground into peanut butter.

pages.A.title: Strawberry
pages.A.text: A sweet, red fruit used in a variety of condiments and desserts.
pages.B.title: Tomato
pages.B.text: A savory, red $(l)fruit$() often sliced for dishes or squeezed for sauces and soups.

pages.A.title: Coffee
pages.A.text: The fruit of a coffee tree, known as a cherry. The pit (bean) can be roasted, ground, and brewed a delicious beverage.
pages.B.title: Tea
pages.B.text: The leaves of a tea plant. These can be dried, processed, and brewed to make a relaxing beverage.

pages.A.title: Hops
pages.A.text: The seed cones of a flowering hop vine. Used to flavor beer.
pages.B.title: Frost Melon
pages.B.text: A blue cultivar of melon. Those who consume it find that even the hottest of surfaces feel icy.

pages.A.title: Fluxtooth
pages.A.text: A pale mushroom that exudes a viscous, redstone-like emulsion when mature.
pages.B.title: Glimmercap
pages.B.text: A glowing fungus that produces a thin layer of shimmering, golden powder on its cap.

pages.A.title: Boomshroom
pages.A.text: A temperamental mushroom that grows webs of explosive material on its underside.
pages.B.title: Slitake
pages.B.text: A gooey fungus that secretes protective slime, which can be congealed into balls.
